lessons.title: Internet and IP Addresses
masteryOutcomes: Define the internet as a network of connected computers
Define what an IP address is
Understand why computers need IP addresses to communicate

lessons.title: Clients and Servers
masteryOutcomes: Define client and server
Understand how clients and servers interact
Identify clients and servers in common real-world examples

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: Internet and IP address scavenger hunt
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Learners will be able to correctly identify and classify examples of the internet, networks, and IP addresses in real-life scenarios.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Network tab explorer
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Learn to use browser DevTools to locate and inspect HTTP requests and responses made by a real web page. Output: A short report (notes or screenshots) listing at least three captured requests with their method, URL, status, and response type.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: API action detective

Output: A filled-in table mapping several captured requests to plain-language descriptions of the API actions they represent.

This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.

lessons.title: Parsing JSON Responses
masteryOutcomes: Convert a response body to JSON
Access JSON data using Python dictionaries and lists
Extract specific fields from a JSON response

lessons.title: Query Parameters in Python
masteryOutcomes: Send query parameters using `requests`

Match Python requests to documented endpoints

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Book search with JSON parsing
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice converting response bodies to JSON, navigating nested dictionaries/lists, and extracting specific fields from a JSON response. Output: A script that searches for books by a fixed keyword and prints a short list of titles and authors.

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: Postman-Python mapping quiz
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Reinforce conceptual understanding of how Postman request components (method, URL, headers, params, body) map to Python `requests` arguments through a non-coding quiz and matching exercise.
